Authors: Andrzej Grzywacz, James Wallman, Marcin Piwczynski
Title:
To be, or not to be a valid genus: the systematic position of
Ophyra R.-D. (Diptera: Muscidae) revised
Keywords:
Muscidae, Hydrotaea, Ophyra, phylogenetics, taxon
sampling, molecular phylogeny
Abstract:
Ophyra Robineau-Desvoidy is one of the better-studied
genera of the family Muscidae (Diptera). The larvae of species of this
genus feed initially on highly decomposed organic matter of various
origins, such as faecal material, carrion and human cadavers, although
they reveal predatory behaviour as they mature. These feeding habits,
combined with the widespread distribution and close association with
human dwellings of some species, give the genus great commercial and
medico-legal importance. However, the systematic position of Ophyra has
been a matter of debate for many years. Ophyra has been considered by
muscid workers to be either a valid genus or a junior synonym of
Hydrotaea. These genera, in the former sense, can only be distinguished
by the fore leg ornamentation of males. A lack of agreement about the
systematic position of Ophyra raises confusion among researchers and
even serious errors, particularly in the applied literature. Recent
molecular and morphological studies provided contradictory information
on the validity of the genus Ophyra and its subfamilial classification.
We revise the systematic position of Ophyra herein by means of molecular
phylogenetic reconstruction. Our results are incongruent with opinions
on the systematic position of Ophyra based on previously published
molecular phylogenies, however they correspond with the concept of the
genus based on adult morphology. All analyses of the concatenated
dataset have revealed Ophyra as monophyletic and placed within a
paraphyletic Azeliini. Depending on the statistical approach, Ophyra has
been placed within either a monophyletic, paraphyletic or polyphyletic
Hydrotaea, yet always closely related to a certain group of species. We
also discuss distinct differences in branch support values obtained from
different statistical approaches and their implications for subsequent
phylogenetic conclusions. Our study showed that inappropriate taxon
sampling can distinctly bias the results and that increased sampling of
closely related species considerably increased the accuracy of
phylogenetic reconstruction. We conjecture that some of the differences
between our results and those of previous studies, which are possibly
artefacts, could be avoided if increased taxon sampling had been used by
previous authors. We conclude that Ophyra should be considered a junior
synonym of Hydrotaea, yet a detailed reconstruction of the genus
Hydrotaea awaits future studies with increases in both taxon sampling
and the number of molecular markers.
